at the end of this budget.

   INTERNATIONAL

   OLYMPICS

   OLY-IOC-MEETINGS _ LAUSANNE, Switzerland _ The IOC executive
board concludes meetings, at which it was expected to confirm
expulsion recommendations for six members. (Roughton, Cox News
Service).

   EDs: Moving in (s) Sports and (i) International categories.

   WITH

   OLY-SCALLY-CHECKS _ The Salt Lake Olympic bid group sent $14,500
in 23 separate checks to Atlantan Raouf Scally, whom it believed
was related to Algerian IOC member Mohamed Zerguini. Turns out, he
is the grandson of the late Hadj Mohammed Benjoullen of Morocco,
who died two years ago. Scally's uncle is Atlanta restarateur Rafih
Benjelloun, who had plenty of contacts with Olympic people but said
Scally did not. (Fish, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 40.

   EDs: Moving in (s) Sports and (i) International categories.

   HAITI-EXODUS _ SAINT MARC, Haiti _ In the teeming, dust-caked
villages and dirt poor farms outside the capital city of
Port-Au-Prince, the sun-parched country people of Haiti have a
saying about the United States. ``That's where the water pipe is
cold,'' they say. Mona Emile's husband believed it. Nadier
Austinville's son did too. So for ten years Emile's husband planned
and saved. Austinville sold her farm, her cow and scraped together
$3,000 for her son. Then, the neighbors kissed their wives and
mothers, said good-bye to their six children, and climbed aboard
the country's newest underground railroad to the United States.
More often than not, it is a trip that carries its passengers and
their famililes into an ocean of the unknown where they can vanish
for months, sometimes forever. (Staletovich, Palm Beach Post). 50.
WITH PHOTOS.

   JOURNAL-RUSSIA _ MOSCOW _ Since Russia's economy crashed and
burned last August, it has not been easy to find good news to
report from the capital. Perhaps now let us praise a few things
that _ well, let's be blunt here _ actually WORK WELL in Russia.
Operating in a market economy may give Russians a fit, but
operating in a blizzard is ``byez problemah'' _ without a care.
Armies of snow removal trucks deploy on the roads day and night to
clean the streets while the extensive Moscow subway system handles
millions of riders a day. And the centralized heating system works
so well that on some winter days it may be sub-zero outside while
it is shorts-and-t-shirt weather in your apartment.

   (Holmes, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTO.

   EDs: Moving in (i) International and (k) Commentary categories.

   NATIONAL

   TRAINWRECK _ BOURBONNAIS, Ill. _ Rescue workers climbed through
a twisted, charred rail car with little hope of finding anyone
alive after Amtrak's City of New Orleans plowed into a truck loaded
with steel bars. At least 12 people were killed and six to eight
others were feared dead. (Konigsmark/Manuel, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   SURVIVOR _ Interview with a New Orleans couple headed home on
the train when it wrecked. (Konigsmark, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   DOW-MAGICMARK _ The Dow Jones industrial average opened on the
downside today but quickly mounted a furious rally and passed the
magic 10,000 mark at 9:51 a.m. before retreating. Traders and
analysts compared the milestone to the breaking of the sound
barrier and reaching the moon. ``I never thought I'd see this,''
marvelled Larry Wachtel, a veteran analyst for Prudential
Securities. ``I am 66, have been on the Street 38 years, and this
is really something.'' (Walker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   EDs: Moving in the (a) General News categories and (f) Financial
categories.

   BAPTISTS-LYONS _ ST. PETERSBURG _ The Rev. Henry Lyons is
expected to resign Tuesday as president of National Baptist
Convention USA, about two weeks after being convicted of
racketeering and grand theft. (MWilliams, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   BAPTISTS-NEWPREZ _ Profile of the Rev. S.C. Cureton of Mauldin,
S.C., expected to be tapped as the new leader of the National
Baptist Convention. (Riddle, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   JEWELL-SOURCES _ The judge has ruled again that AJC reporters
must name their sources for stories saying Richard Jewell was the
prime suspect in the Olympic Park bombing.

   (Croft, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   CLINTON-FUNDRAISER _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., and SEWALL's POINT,
Fla. _ Air Force One is scheduled to land at 6:45 p.m. EST at Palm
Beach International Airport. President Clinton will then fly via
helicopter (Marine One) to Witham Field in Stuart. From there he
will travel via limo to the home of attorney Willie Gary for a
$5,000-a-plate fundraiser for the Democratic National Committee.
He's scheduled to depart PBIA at 10:20 p.m. EST. (developing)
(Lambert/Taylor, Palm Beach Post).

   BREWERY-BUSH _ LONGVIEW, Texas _ Union officials representing
Longview Stroh Brewery employees said they think they had a
productive meeting last week in Austin when they talked to Gov.
George W. Bush and his staff members about the troubled brewery.
The problem is, Bush's staff doesn't recall talking with the union
representatives about the brewery, which could close unless another
company buys the plant. (Ferguson, Longview News-Journal). MOVED.

   EDs: Moved to Texas papers only.

   FLA-ILLEGAL-INS _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ The promise of jobs
fuels the business of migrant smuggling, and Florida offers a land
of opportunity for those who sneak across its borders.
``Personally, I believe that, if you focused on employees and
contractors and take away all sources of employment . . . you can
literally turn your back on the borders,'' said Billy Kring, former
chief of the U.S. Border Patrol in Miami. The Immigration and
Naturalization Service, which oversees the Border Patrol, does just
the opposite. It focuses on border security. An illegal job market
flourishes in Florida, prompting growing numbers of migrants to
turn to smugglers. And smugglers operate in a climate of acceptable
risk: a Border Patrol in Florida that hasn't seen an increase in
manpower in 10 years, a Coast Guard patrolling a region strewn with
islands of safe havens, courts wrestling with complex immigration
law and juries sympathetic toward refugees. (Kane, Palm Beach Post)
MOVED.

   WITH

   FLA-SMUGGLERS _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ It's a crime with
built-in deniability. This is how it plays out: A U.S. Coast Guard
patrol stops a high-speed boat off the Florida Keys. It finds a
dozen Cuban passengers aboard. The boat's captain explains that he
happened to be fishing when he spotted the Cubans struggling in a
sinking raft. Though the passengers show no signs of fatigue,
dehydration or injury, they confirm the story and insist the
captain be treated as a hero. Smuggling cases are difficult to
prosecute because often the only witness to the crime is the
smuggled human cargo. And people who spend their life savings in a
desperate bid to get into the United States make reluctant
witnesses, prosecutors say. (Kane, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   BAXTER-COLUMN _ This year the Georgia Senate and House have
undergone a widely noted role reversal. In the House, where party
hostilities used to crackle, bills routinely pass with large
bipartisan majorities and party leaders rise, more often than they
did before at least, to thank the other party for its cooperation.
It's the other side of the building, where members of the two
parties used to get along in such chummy fashion, that has become
the partisan arena. (Baxter, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED
MONDAY.

   WASHINGTON/POLITICS

   MEDICARE _ WASHINGTON _ A divided National Bipartisan Commission
on the Future of Medicare holds an open meeting to vote on reform
recommendations. (Lipman, Cox News Service).

   Eds: meeting starts at 5 p.m. EST.

a.m., and sports and business budgets at 6 p.m. Additional updates
are possible if news developments warrant.

   All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given.
